lg.l: To The Revd Dr Trusler

Revd. SirBlake places the superscript "d" above a period. These are presented as consecutive characters in the transcription of this line. Bentley (Writings volume 2, page 1524) places the superscript "d" directly above the period. Keynes (Letters, page 6) and Erdman (page 701) omit the period below the superscript "d".
I find more & more that my Style of Designing is
a Species by itself & in this which I send you have been
compelld by my Genius or Angel to follow where he led
if I were to act otherwise it would not fulfill the purpose
for which alone I live. which is in conjunction with
such men as my friend Cumberland to renew the lost
Art of the Greeks
I attempted every morning for a fortnight together to
follow your Dictate but when I found my attempts were
in vain. resolvedresolvd to shew an independence which I know
will please anyaAuthor better than slavishly following the
track of another however admirable that track may be
At any rate my Excuse must be; I could not do otherwise,
it was out of my power!
I know I begged of you to give me your Ideas
& promised to build on them here I counted without my
host I now find my mistake
The Design I have Sent. Is
A Father taking leave of his Wife & Child. Is

lg.l: watchd by Two Fiends incarnate. with intention thatKeynes (Letters, page 7) reads "watchd" as "watched".
when his back is turned they will murder the mother
& her infant. If this is not Malevolence with a
vengeance I have never seen it on Earth. & If youErdman (page 701) and Keynes (Letters, page 7) read "If" as "if".
approve of this I have no doubt of giving you
Benevolence with Equal Vigor. as also Pride &
Humility. but cannot previously describe in words
what I mean to Design for fear I should Evaporate
the Spirit of my Invention. But I hope that noneErdman (page 701) reads "some of m" underneath the overwritten script of "the Spirit".
of my Designs will be destitute of Infinite Particulars
which will present themselves to the Contemplator. And
tho I call them Mine I know that they are not Mine
being of the same opinion with Milton when he says That
the Muse visits his Slumbers & awakes & governs his Song
when Morn purples the East. & being also in the predicamentErdman (page 701) reads "the East" as "The East".
of that prophet who says I cannot go beyond the command
of the Lord to speak good or bad
If you approve of my Manner & it is agreeable
to you. I would rather Paint Pictures in oil of the
same dimensions than make Drawings & on the
